trial_identification.studytitle: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Esoteric Connective Tissue Therapy on Chronic Low Back Pain
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Esoteric Connective Tissue Therapy on Chronic Low Back Pain

interventions.interventions: Esoteric Connective Tissue Therapy (ECTT) Materials: Participant Information and Consent Form Procedures: Esoteric Connective Tissue Therapy The treatment consists of small circular motions, primarily with a diameter of 23.5cm to the legs, arms and head, with the motions to the head being even smaller. Further actions involve techniques for gently holding the hip, knee, ankle, back and spine, allowing the body to adjust (align). Who: Two ECTT Practitioners with eight years' experience each. One per patient. Mode of delivery: Face to face, client lies on massage table Number of times: Four 40 minute sessions, once per week for four weeks Location: Hospital Personalisation: No personalisation Adherence: Each session is recorded by the nursing staff.
interventions.comparator:
Physiotherapy Materials: Participant Information and Consent Form, Heat Lamp, TENS machine, electro-acupuncture, vibrating handheld massage tool Procedures:
Massage of low back for 15 minutes: Slapping with cupped hands to increase movement Circular massage movement on low back. Further slapping with cupped hands. Using thumbs on each side of spine along the spine. Kneading of skin and underlying muscles.
TENS (Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation) machine for 15 minutes using 9V electrical pulses transmitted via electrodes placed on the skin at the low back area of pain.
Electro-acupuncture with 250W UV heat lamp for 20 minutes. Electro-acupuncture applies a pulsating electrical current to acupuncture needles which are placed on the low back of the client. The current is 50Hz, 90-120V, 10-80 milliamps with the highest setting used that the patient is comfortable with. The heat lamp is 250W and 50cm distant from the patient's low back.
Who: Physiotherapy nurses with three years' training Mode of delivery: Face to face, client lies on massage table Number of times: Four 50 minute sessions, once per week for four weeks Location: Hospital Personalisation: No personalisation except for intensity of TENS and electro-acupuncture stimulation. Adherence: Each session is recorded by the nursing staff.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain levels as measured by the Visual Analogue Pain Scale
Pain functionality as measured by the the Quebec Back Pain Disability Scale.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Correlation between change in pain level and initial pain intensity, assessed by visual analogue scale.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: * Aged over 18, able to speak, read and write Vietnamese. * Suffering from chronic low back pain which according to the NIH taskforces definition is pain for at least half the days in the past six months. * At evaluation time suffering from low back pain at a minimum 40 out of 100 on the Visual Analogue Pain Scale. * Physically able to undertake the standard physiotherapy treatment given by the hospitals Able to fill in the SF-36 questionnaire and the Quebec Pain Functionality questionnaire with the writing done by themselves or the hospital staff.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: * Being pregnant * If the patient is not sure whether she is pregnant. * Clinically Diagnosed Schizophrenia, Bipolar conditions and or states including Mania and Delirium, Psychosis or showing any signs of Psychosis, Borderline Disorder or Major Depressive Disorder * Diagnosed or suspected neoplasm * Severe joint degeneration causing pain of a mechanical nature in the spine, hip or knees * Past surgery to the spine * Osteoporotic fracture or infection.

trial_design.sequence: Using the website “sealed envelope” URL: https://www.sealedenvelope.com/simple-randomiser/v1/lists downloaded 7/8/2015 with a random block randomised design for 200 subjects and an overall limit of 100 participants. The seed used is “8”.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: a. Satterthwaite's t-test to compare means of treatment and control groups at primary endpoints. In a phase I/II study by a physiotherapist (unpublished), Kate Greenaway, the mean pain score for participants with a starting pain level of 30/100 or more improved by 28mm with an sd of 20mm after five treatments. Assuming a 10mm improvement in the control group with the same standard deviation, a power (beta) of 0.8 and a=0.05, we need a sample size of 2x21=42 for Satterthwaites t-test to have a statistically significant (p<0.05) result, ignoring crossovers and withdrawals. Hence 50 participants in each group could well be sufficient. As the pain score is longitudinal data, multi-level modelling will also be employed in the analysis of the pain score.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: School of Public Health University of Queensland Herston Road Herston, QLD 4006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The primary purpose of the study is to ascertain how a newly developed complementary-to-medicine low intervention therapy called Esoteric Connective Tissue Therapy (ECTT) compares to the standard treatment, physiotherapy, for chronic low back pain. The main hypotheses are that ECTT provides a larger improvement than physiotherapy in a. pain reduction as measured on the 0-100 Visual Analogue Pain Scale, b. physical and mental well-being as scored by the SF-36 questionnaire or c. pain functionality as measured by the Quebec Back Pain Disability Scale.
ethicsAndSummary.publicnotes: There is no funding. The researchers are all unpaid volunteers who cover their own costs. The hospitals provide their facilities and personnel free of charge.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: University of Queensland appointed for full ethical approvals: Bellberry Pty Ltd
